hero.headline: Stone Retrieval
hero.description: Lithotripsy systems face unique challenges proving effective stone fragmentation while minimizing urothelial injury and surrounding tissue trauma. We test fragmentation efficiency, energy delivery accuracy, and tissue preservation using standardized stone models that address extracorporeal, laser, and ultrasonic lithotripsy technologies.

primary_content.title: Our Preclinical Expertise
primary_content.description:
Stone fragmentation devices must demonstrate effective urolithiasis treatment across varying stone composition and size characteristics while proving tissue safety throughout repeated treatment applications. Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy requires focal zone positioning accuracy validation ensuring energy delivery concentrates at stone locations without damaging surrounding structures. Laser lithotripsy platforms need fiber delivery system characterization showing consistent energy transmission throughout ureteroscopic procedures. Ultrasonic fragmentation devices demand probe contact efficiency assessment measuring vibration transmission that disintegrates stones while preserving urothelial tissue integrity. Each modality addresses different stone composition challenges requiring validated effectiveness protocols.

We evaluate lithotripsy performance through standardized synthetic stone models replicating calcium oxalate, uric acid, cystine, and struvite composition hardness characteristics encountered clinically while measuring fragmentation efficiency, particle size distribution, and complete clearance capability. Energy delivery characterization uses dosimetry measurement documenting shock wave pressure amplitudes, laser pulse energies, and ultrasonic power levels throughout treatment sequences. High-speed imaging captures fragmentation mechanisms and particle trajectory patterns while tissue effect protocols assess thermal injury potential, mechanical trauma extent, and urothelial preservation. Advanced imaging modalities track stone localization accuracy and treatment progression throughout procedures.

IEC 61846 shock wave lithotripters safety standard guides extracorporeal system validation while device-specific protocols address laser safety per IEC 60825 and ultrasonic energy characterization requirements. Testing supports 510(k) pathways for devices demonstrating substantial equivalence to cleared lithotripsy platforms and addresses comprehensive safety validation for breakthrough fragmentation technologies. Whether characterizing extracorporeal shock wave systems, validating holmium laser lithotripsy effectiveness, or assessing ultrasonic probe fragmentation efficiency, our protocols generate data meeting urological stone management device regulatory expectations.

capabilities.title: Stone Fragmentation Efficiency
capabilities.description: Standardized stone model protocols quantify fragmentation completeness across composition types while measuring treatment duration requirements, fragment size distributions, and clearance capability that determine clinical stone-free rate achievement and procedure success.

capabilities.title: Focal Zone Positioning Accuracy
capabilities.description: Imaging guidance validation characterizes stone localization precision and energy delivery targeting accuracy while measuring focal zone dimensions and positioning reproducibility that determine effective treatment without collateral tissue damage.

capabilities.title: Laser Energy Delivery
capabilities.description: Fiber optic transmission efficiency testing measures laser pulse energy consistency throughout ureteroscopic working distances while characterizing power stability, beam profile quality, and fiber durability under repeated activation cycles.

capabilities.title: Thermal Injury Assessment
capabilities.description: Temperature mapping during energy application quantifies thermal distribution patterns and peak tissue temperatures while measuring coagulation zone dimensions and thermal damage extent that determine urothelial safety and complication prevention.

capabilities.title: Mechanical Trauma Evaluation
capabilities.description: Tissue effect protocols assess urothelial perforation risk, hematoma formation potential, and vessel injury patterns while measuring mechanical trauma severity from shock wave pressure, laser pulse impact, or ultrasonic probe contact.

capabilities.title: Treatment Monitoring Capabilities
capabilities.description: Real-time imaging integration validates stone visualization quality throughout procedures while measuring treatment progression assessment capability and fragment clearance confirmation that determine procedure endpoint determination and completion verification.

cards.title: Stone Management Expertise
cards.description: Validated urological intervention models enable realistic assessment of lithotripsy device performance across anatomical locations including kidney, ureter, and bladder stone scenarios. Our team understands stone composition variation, fragmentation mechanism differences across energy modalities, and the specific safety and effectiveness endpoints stone management device manufacturers must demonstrate for regulatory approvals and clinical adoption.
